author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: CHAPTER 3 A Peculiar Imprisonment   From a slumber as deep as death as refreshing as that of a healthy child I slowly awakened

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: It was like rising up up up through a deep warm ocean nearer and nearer to full light and stirring air

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Or like the return to consciousness after concussion of the brain

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: I was once thrown from a horse while on a visit to a wild mountainous country quite new to me and I can clearly remember the mental experience of coming back to life through lifting veils of dream

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: When I first dimly heard the voices of those about me and saw the shining snowpeaks of that mighty range I assumed that this too would pass and I should presently find myself in my own home

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: That was precisely the experience of this awakening receding waves of halfcaught swirling vision memories of home the steamer the boat the airship the forestat last all sinking away one after another till my eyes were wide open my brain clear and I realized what had happened

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: The most prominent sensation was of absolute physical comfort

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: I was lying in a perfect bed long broad smooth firmly soft and level with the finest linen some warm light quilt of blanket and a counterpane that was a joy to the eye

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: The sheet turned down some fifteen inches yet I could stretch my feet at the foot of the bed free but warmly covered

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: I felt as light and clean as a white feather

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: It took me some time to conscientiously locate my arms and legs to feel the vivid sense of life radiate from the wakening center to the extremities

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland

title: Herland

title: Herland

title: Herland

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: What happened to them first was merely a succession of historic misfortunes such as have befallen other nations often enough

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: They were decimated by war driven up from their coastline till finally the reduced population with many of the men killed in battle occupied this hinterland and defended it for years in the mountain passes

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Where it was open to any possible attack from below they strengthened the natural defenses so that it became unscalably secure as we found it

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: They were a polygamous people and a slaveholding people like all of their time and during the generation or two of this struggle to defend their mountain home they built the fortresses such as the one we were held in and other of their oldest buildings some still in use

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Nothing but earthquakes could destroy such architecturehuge solid blocks holding by their own weight

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: They must have had efficient workmen and enough of them in those days

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: They made a brave fight for their existence but no nation can stand up against what the steamship companies call an act of God

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: While the whole fighting force was doing its best to defend their mountain pathway there occurred a volcanic outburst with some local tremors and the result was the complete filling up of the passtheir only outlet

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Instead of a passage a new ridge sheer and high stood between them and the sea they were walled in and beneath that wall lay their whole little army

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Very few men were left alive save the slaves and these now seized their opportunity rose in revolt killed their remaining masters even to the youngest boy killed the old women too and the mothers intending to take possession of the country with the remaining young women and girls

title: Herland

title: Herland
words: I did my best keenly interested as I have always been in sociology and social psychology to reconstruct in my mind the real position of these ancient women

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: There were some five or six hundred of them and they were harembred yet for the few preceding generations they had been reared in the atmosphere of such heroic struggle that the stock must have been toughened somewhat

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Left alone in that terrific orphanhood they had clung together supporting one another and their little sisters and developing unknown powers in the stress of new necessity

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: To this painhardened and workstrengthened group who had lost not only the love and care of parents but the hope of ever having children of their own there now dawned the new hope

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Here at last was Motherhood and though it was not for all of them personally it mightif the power was inheritedfound here a new race

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: It may be imagined how those five Daughters of Maaia Children of the Temple Mothers of the Futurethey had all the titles that love and hope and reverence could givewere reared

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: The whole little nation of women surrounded them with loving service and waited between a boundless hope and an equally boundless despair to see if they too would be mothers

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: And they were

title: Herland

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Presently there were twentyfive New Women Mothers in their own right and the whole spirit of the country changed from mourning and mere courageous resignation to proud joy

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: The older women those who remembered men died off the youngest of all the first lot of course died too after a while and by that time there were left one hundred and fiftyfive parthenogenetic women founding a new race

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: They inherited all that the devoted care of that declining band of original ones could leave them

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Their farms and gardens were all in full production

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Such industries as they had were in careful order

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: The records of their past were all preserved and for years the older women had spent their time in the best teaching they were capable of that they might leave to the little group of sisters and mothers all they possessed of skill and knowledge

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: There you have the start of Herland

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: One family all descended from one mother

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: She lived to a hundred years old lived to see her hundred and twentyfive greatgranddaughters born lived as QueenPriestessMother of them all and died with a nobler pride and a fuller joy than perhaps any human soul has ever knownshe alone had founded a new race

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: The first five daughters had grown up in an atmosphere of holy calm of awed watchful waiting of breathless prayer

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: To them the longedfor motherhood was not only a personal joy but a nations hope

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Their twentyfive daughters in turn with a stronger hope a richer wider outlook with the devoted love and care of all the surviving population grew up as a holy sisterhood their whole ardent youth looking forward to their great office

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: And at last they were left alone the whitehaired First Mother was gone and this one family five sisters twentyfive first cousins and a hundred and twentyfive second cousins began a new race

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: The big difference was that whereas our children grow up in private homes and families with every effort made to protect and seclude them from a dangerous world here they grew up in a wide friendly world and knew it for theirs from the first

title: Herland
words: We have two life cycles the mans and the womans

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: To the woman growth the securing of a husband the subordinate activities of family life and afterward such social or charitable interests as her position allows

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: Here was but one cycle and that a large one

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: The child entered upon a broad open field of life in which motherhood was the one great personal contribution to the national life and all the rest the individual share in their common activities

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland

title: Herland

author: Gilman, Charlotte Perkins
title: Herland
words: The Herland child was born not only into a world carefully prepared full of the most fascinating materials and opportunities to learn but into the society of plentiful numbers of teachers teachers born and trained whose business it was to accompany the children along that to us impossible thingthe royal road to learning
